I'm running the Search as Infocenter with Tomcat 4.0.4b2. I have eclipse build M5 and I'm 
experiencing the following Exception when starting to 
search.

java.lang.StringIndexOutOfBoundsException: String index out of range: 5
        at 
java.lang.String.substring(String.java:1473)
        at 
org.eclipse.help.internal.protocols.HelpURL.getLocale(HelpURL.java:126)
        at 
org.eclipse.help.internal.protocols.PluginURL.openStream(PluginURL.java:81)
        at 
org.eclipse.help.internal.protocols.HelpURLConnection.getInputStream(HelpURLConnection.java:30)
 
       at java.net.URL.openStream(URL.java:955)
        at 
org.eclipse.help.internal.search.IndexingOperation.add(IndexingOperation.java:46)
 
       at 
org.eclipse.help.internal.search.IndexingOperation.execute(IndexingOperation.java:125)
 
       at 
org.eclipse.help.internal.search.SearchManager.updateIndex(SearchManager.java:246)
 
       at org.eclipse.help.internal.protocols.SearchURL$1.run(SearchURL.java:81)
        at 
java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:536)

I already had a look into the Source and had a 
workaround for this problem. I tried to reproduce the problem with Opera 6 and IE6 and also to fix 
it. I changed the Accept-Language Header for the HTTP Request to something like de_DE or en_US. 
This fixed the problem and the indexing continued as expected and came back with a result. I was 
surprised to see that the language ID doesn't fix the problem in general. It must be something in 
the above mentioned form.

I will fix the exception, but in general, the infocenter is supposed to serve 
documents for any locale, so we look at the request to determine what the 
locale should be (i.e. pick up the User Agent info). It is the responsibility 
of the infocenter publisher to ensure correct requests.

Try the nightly build that's available tomorrow and see if search in the 
infocenter scenarios is fixed.
Closing the bug as we can no longer reproduce it after the fix.
